ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about the different theories and research of societal collapse from centuries ago to more modern day, and mostly climate change's role in all of them
I learned how to critically read scholarly papers and decipher strength and weaknesses from comparative perspectives on a topic.
I learned about what it means for a society to collapse, and how to apply that theory to numerous examples.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: learn a lot about collapse (something I knew nothing about), discussion section you get to dive a little deeper and reflect on readings. Assignments are rather light throughout the semester. 

Weaknesses: although it's a seminar the students do not discuss during class, professor lectures the entire time (except for when student presentations start but that's only about 20 mins of the class)
I loved learning from Professor Weiss. He was amazing. It could be improved by more transparency around section existence prior to the start of term.

The lectures are fascinating, and the readings are interesting (though sometimes way too technical). The discussions with Professor Weiss are wonderful, yet he makes it very clear what he sees as right and wrong in the field. That perspective is very interesting though.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: definitely take it, such an interesting experience; never a dull moment
If fulfilling EVST or other credit, sure, but otherwise there may be more exciting classes at Yale.
Yes if they are interested in history/archaeology/societal evolution
Absolutely. The lectures are engaging and Professor Weiss is extremely charismatic.
I would recommend the class. It was truly very fascinating. The class experience was very dependent on your TA though.
